abstract: Despite rules empowering shareholders to rein in soaring pay packages, few have chosen to do so, perhaps because of a rising stock market.
snippet: Despite rules empowering shareholders to rein in soaring pay packages, few have chosen to do so, perhaps because of a rising stock market.
lead_paragraph: It’s been five years since the Dodd-Frank law required that companies let investors vote on their executive pay practices. The idea, lawmakers said, was to give shareholders a chance to sound off when compensation plans are not in their best interests.

headline.main: Shareholders’ Votes Have Done Little to Curb Lavish Executive Pay
headline.print_headline: Shareholders’ Votes Have Done Little to Curb the Festivities
